why: Primary CHNS baseline: Table 2 Col 1 post_FILdie on loghrindinc_real with individual + year*province FE
Baseline + marriage duration and health controls -- same outcome/treatment with additional covariates
FE only with no demographic controls -- tests sensitivity to control set
Only age polynomial controls -- partial control set
Age polynomials + education dummies only -- no household composition controls
Age polynomials + household composition but no education dummies
Age + education + marriage duration + health status (no household vars)
Full controls including employment sector variables -- strongest result (p=0.020)
Linear age instead of cubic polynomial -- tests sensitivity to age functional form
Quadratic age instead of cubic polynomial -- tests sensitivity to age functional form
Individual FE only (no year*province) -- removes time-region trends
Individual + Year FE (no province interaction) -- alternative time structure
Individual + Province FE -- identical to unit_only since province is collinear with individual FE
Individual + Year + Province (separate FE) -- additive FE instead of year*province interaction
Pooled OLS without individual FE -- tests importance of within-individual variation (near-zero insignificant coef confirms FE is essential)
First differences instead of fixed effects -- alternative panel estimator
Robust (HC) SE instead of individual-clustered SE -- same coefficient different inference
Province-clustered SE instead of individual-clustered -- accounts for within-province correlation
Wider age range 20-50 (baseline is 22-45) -- tests sensitivity to age restriction
Narrower age range 25-40 -- tests sensitivity to age restriction (loses power)
Include rural observations (baseline is urban only) -- effect nearly vanishes consistent with urban nepotism mechanism
Include 1989 wave -- duplicate of baseline (identical coefficients indicate 1989 was already included or has no FIL events)
Restrict to men who actually experience FIL death -- strongest result (p=0.003) leverages within-treated variation only
Drop singleton observations -- duplicate of baseline (identical coefficients indicate no singletons in baseline sample)
Pre-1997 waves only -- tests whether effect is driven by pre-reform era (larger coef -0.298 but imprecise)
Post-1997 waves only -- effect weakens substantially (p=0.62) consistent with reform reducing nepotism
Dependent variable winsorized at 1st/99th percentile -- tests outlier sensitivity
Dependent variable winsorized at 5th/95th percentile -- more aggressive outlier trimming
Mother-in-law death as treatment instead of FIL -- placebo/falsification test (positive insignificant as expected)
MIL death with extended controls -- placebo/falsification (positive insignificant)
FIL death controlling for MIL death -- adds MIL death as control to isolate FIL-specific effect
FIL death controlling for MIL death with extended controls
FIL death effect conditional on MIL alive -- heterogeneity by MIL survival status
FIL death effect conditional on MIL already dead -- heterogeneity by MIL survival status (insignificant as expected)
FIL death with post-1997 reform interaction -- tests time-varying effect magnitude
Job change as outcome instead of log income -- tests labor mobility channel
Job change with extended controls -- different outcome variable
Level income instead of log income -- tests functional form of outcome
Hours worked per week as outcome -- tests labor supply channel (positive insignificant)
Total household food expenditure as outcome -- tests consumption channel (significant p=0.007)
Log household purchases as outcome -- tests consumption channel
Log rent/housing value as outcome -- tests housing/wealth channel
Hours per week at household level -- different sample and aggregation
Move/attrition indicator as outcome -- tests selective attrition (marginally significant p=0.086)
Female own father death on female earnings -- placebo (positive insignificant as expected for asymmetric gender mechanism)
Female own father death with extended controls -- placebo
Primary SLCC baseline: Table 2 Col 1 post_fILdie_male on logincom_male with individual + year*province FE
SLCC baseline + marriage duration control -- same outcome/treatment with additional covariate
MIL death effect in SLCC -- placebo/falsification (positive insignificant)
SLCC FIL death controlling for MIL death -- adds MIL death as control
SLCC job change as outcome -- different outcome variable testing labor mobility
SLCC FIL death conditional on MIL alive -- heterogeneity by MIL survival
SLCC with separate year + province FE (not interacted) -- alternative FE structure
SLCC with individual FE only -- removes time-region trends
SLCC pooled OLS -- confirms importance of individual FE (near-zero insignificant)
SLCC wider age range 20-50 -- tests age restriction sensitivity
SLCC narrower age range 25-40 -- loses significance (p=0.29) due to reduced power
SLCC female income placebo -- tests whether FIL death affects women (negative but insignificant)
CHNS state sector subsample -- tests nepotism mechanism (negative but insignificant in subsample)
CHNS collective sector subsample -- largest magnitude (-0.261) but imprecise due to small N
CHNS private sector subsample -- positive insignificant (no nepotism in private sector as predicted)
SLCC state sector subsample -- negative but insignificant
SLCC collective sector subsample -- positive insignificant
SLCC private sector subsample -- negative but very imprecise
Household heads only -- larger effect (-0.186 p=0.012) consistent with heads benefiting more from FIL networks
Non-household-heads only -- near-zero and insignificant
High education subsample (edulevel >= 3) -- negative marginally significant
Low education subsample (edulevel < 3) -- larger magnitude but less precise
Leave-one-out: drop province 21 -- stable coefficient
Leave-one-out: drop province 23 -- stable coefficient
Leave-one-out: drop province 32 -- coefficient drops to -0.075 (most sensitive province)
Leave-one-out: drop province 37 -- coefficient increases to -0.146 (p=0.038)
Leave-one-out: drop province 41 -- stable coefficient
Leave-one-out: drop province 42 -- stable coefficient
Leave-one-out: drop province 43 -- coefficient drops to -0.091
Leave-one-out: drop province 45 -- coefficient slightly larger
Leave-one-out: drop province 52 -- stable coefficient
Exclude divorced/separated individuals -- tests sample composition sensitivity
Age fixed effects instead of age polynomial -- nonparametric age control
